title: What happens to Life Insurance cash value in Ca. Chap. 7 BK ? 3 policy values 12,575, 14,440, 39.462. Is some of it exempt ?
question: We are living on Social Security only supplemented with 401 K and SEP funds. We are renting a house and our cars are leased. We had to sell our home on a short sale. Our SS income is less than the median for Ca. We have not filed yet. We had to surrender our RV and they have filed suit to recover the difference after they resold it. They want $243,000
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Bankruptcy exemptions,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate finances,Short sales,Real estate and bankruptcy,Renting a house or apartment,Real estate,Social security,Representing yourself
answers: You should be able to exempt up to the wild card amount as stated in the above answer, everything else will most likely be distributed to creditors. Consult your local bk attorney your case is certainly not cut and dry.

Generally, filing bankruptcy pro se is not a good idea. If you have ANY assets that may be at risk, filing pro se can be VERY expensive. Get yourself an experience attorney in your area. Your attorney should conduct a complete analysis of your situation, and give you an idea of exactly which assets are at risk. There are actions people can take to protect certain assets before you file. Slow down, get good advise and proceed cautiously.

I hope this helps.
Respectfully,
Steven A. Leahy
www.chicagotaxteam.com

I agree with Mr. Water's answer and especially with his excellent advice regarding pre-bankruptcy planning.

Do yourselves a BIG favor and consult local Chapter 7 (or 13) bankruptcy counsel and, should you decide ultimately to file a petition, have an attorney represent you.

Since you have had a lawsuit filed against you, do not delay, as time is of the essence if you wish all of your options to be available. Good luck.

The amount of cash surrender value of life insurance you can exempt in California depends on which exemption section of the California Code of Civil Procedure you are using. The "703" series of exemptions lets you exempt upt to $12,860 and the "704" series lets you exempt up to $22,950. However, there is also a "wildcard" exemption available under the 703 series that lets you add an additional exemption amount of up to a little over $25,000.00. In a situation where you have too much of a non-exempt asset, you might be able to do some pre-filing planning and convert some non-exempt funds into exempt. If you arrange for a consultation with a local bankruptcy attorney, they will be able to sit down with you and look at your entire financial situation and determine the best approach for you under the bankruptcy code, such as a Chapter 7 versus a Chapter 13, and which exemption sections would be best to use for your assets and the value of those assets. As you have found out, a debt that is "written off" or "charged off" as a bad debt doesn't mean the debt, and your responsibility to pay, goes away. It is merely an accounting term the creditor uses to designate debt accounts they feel they have little or no chance of collecting on. But your liability remains. However, if the underlying debt (in this case your motorhome deficiency) is discharged in a bankruptcy, then the debt, and any related tax associated with the debt (they will send you a 1099C) also goes away. Meet with a local attorney to review everything and do some pre-filing planning and you should have no problems.
